captions.text: Good morning, John. The world is fascinating.

You can take pretty much anything in the world
and drill down far enough to find convoluted

tales of hilarity and intrigue. We're gonna
do that right now... with this.

The pound sign, the number sign, the hash
symbol, different names in different countries,

and understandably. In America, a shifted
three on a standard keyboard is called a pound

sign. In the UK, a shifted three on a standard
keyboard is also called a pound sign, but

they are completely different characters,
what the frick?

Weirdly enough, they actually both have the
same origin: the Latin phrase for weight,

libra pondo. It's the same reason that pound
is abbreviated lb. Despite the fact that that
is super dumb.

Now in the middle of the last millennium,
bookkeepers would scribble so fast while they

were writing down weights that lb started
to look like maybe it was a 16, they weren't

quite sure, it was unclear, so they started
to cross the top of the lb. Their frantic

scribbling intensified to the point where
it started to look like this.

And that there is the missing link between
this, and this. However, this symbol had pretty

much fallen completely out of use until the
end of the 19th century. That's when the Teletype

Corporation was inventing binary codes for
the transmission of letters. In the UK, the

symbol code for the pound sign was 10111.
But in the US, because apparently we don't

need pound signs or even want to look at them,
they decided to make that pound sign not the

UK pound currency symbol, but the old, obsolete
pound sign. This is the moment where the magic
happened.

Because this symbol didn't actually mean very
much, it started to become a catchall symbol

for when someone needed a non-confusing symbol
for something.

This is probably how it became known as the
number sign, you put it before a number to

indicate that the number is a number. Which
is so extremely non-useful that I refuse to

accept that this thing is called a number
sign. I know it's a number because it's a
number!

Next step in the process: Bell Labs is developing
touch tone phones in the 1960s. The engineers

at Bell Labs see the potential for phones
to control machines and computers, so they

want to add two extra buttons that aren't
numbers that can be used for those purposes.

Originally, it was a five-pointed star and
a diamond, but the engineers at the company

insisted that it be a character that was in
the newly created ASCII Code System. And neither
of those symbols were in there.

After much deliberation, they went with the
asterisk which looked a lot like the star

and the kinda unnamed symbol in question because
it wasn't really being used for anything else,
so it wasn't confusing.

So, it was included on phones, and remarkably
enough if I go to the keypad, it's still on

there! Because it was used by Bell Labs on
their phones, it became a standard, culturally

understood symbol so much so that it was included
on the standard American keyboard. Once again,

in place of the British Pound sign, despite
the fact that there was not really any good
use for it.

Now the engineers at Bell Labs in the sixties
seemed to have recognized that there wasn't

a good name for this thing because in their
manuals that they distributed to different

people about how to use their devices, occasionally
when referring to this sign, they would have

a little footnote that would say "also sometimes
known as an octothorpe" or possibly octatherp.

This was a joke, an Easter egg, but it actually
for a couple of decades caught on in the engineering

community because engineers love jargon, and
because, I mean in my opinion at least, octothorpe
is a better word than any of the other options.

Now you might argue that with the arrival
of the social media hashtag, another use by

the way made possible by the symbols prevalence
without having a particular use. Hash sign

seems the logical way to go; that's what it's
called in most of the world, though in America

we still say pound sign even though that's
terribly confusing.

But for those of us who would rather have
our language defined by cheeky nerds of the

1960s than by the whims of social media, for
us, we'll always have octothorpe!
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

Good news everyone, after like a year of working
on this, we have launched a new DFTBA.com

merch store. It's prettier and more functional
and you don't have to use PayPal and you can

buy posters and shirts at the same time.
We've just launched a few new designs, one

of them I've had to blur a little bit. And
one of them is a pre-order for all my octothorpe
lovers out there. Represent. Hashtag octothorpe!

comments.text:
When those engineers put the octothorpe into ASCII, did they realize it's 
basically a sharp sign? That's the French word we use in French to refer to 
it. (Because we like anglicizing words very much)﻿
comments.author: Luapix

comments.text: Where did you get that shirt you're wearing,it looks cool.﻿
comments.author: Neafia

comments.text:
So, I have a story about this that is neither interesting nor funny but it 
affected me in a small way so maybe it will affect you. I used to work at a 
call center and frequently had to tell people the sequence of keys 
"##72786#" and this was constantly met with confusion, as people in today's 
society no longer use the word "pound" in the traditional American sense in 
lieu of "number sign" or "hashtag". I would get really, really annoyed by 
this thinking that society was succumbing to idiocy, but in reality this is 
something that is continuously happening in the development of our 
language. After watching this, I started telling people the origin of their 
beloved hashtag, and while some people accepted this light heartedly to 
fill otherwise awkward silences, more often it was met with awkward 
silence. And it just goes to show that all of us in Nerdfighteria exist in 
a community of people that fully support and accept each others 
intellectual whims while in the majority of society we are not so lucky. 
Plus that job was awful.﻿
comments.author: Kira Shaputis

comments.text:
The reason it's called number-sign isn't so you know what comes after is a 
number, it's so you know it's not an amount, but instead the number itself 
is the reference; an issued number.

"He was given the #4 ping pong balls."
"He was given the 4 ping pong balls."

Those read differently, because you immediately know you get the ping pong 
balls designated as type number 4, not the amount, 4.﻿

That's is really kind of interesting. In Swedish, we call it 'fyrkant' or

comments.author: Grace Nalasco (Tadpole)

comments.text:
Hi Hank,
I certainly enjoyed your excellent exploration of the " # ". However, I 
must defend its use as the "number sign". Some numbers are not mathematical 
values, for example your telephone number or street address. For instance, 
multiplying them together yields a meaningless number. The octothorpe 
serves as a signal that the number being used is describing an ordering or 
label, but not a computational value. 
Long live the octothorpe!
Thanks again. ﻿

comments.text:
Interesting enough, I work at a veterinarian office and we use # in front 
of a number to indicate how many meds total go in a bottle; for example #30 
means 30 pills. We use the # after a number to indicate weight, so a dog 
might weigh 55#.  I think that 2nd one goes along with the "pound" usage of 
the symbol. So, my point being, it has adapted its way into even the 
medical field. :) ﻿

Linguists use # to mark word boundaries, aka the end of a word.  So when 
we're isolating sound environments and the sound is at the beginning of a 
word we use # to mark that.  The more you know!﻿

On Polish keyboards an alternative to Polish letters absent in English from 
the right Alt Gr is to use Shift+` i.e. ~ and then press the key. I 
happened to discover that option first, though the former is far more 
efficient.
In my personal use, I use it to indicate uncertainty, approximately, 
geometric similarity, or in lazy mathematics approximately equal to. (Pi ~= 
3.14) I never use ` though.

comments.text:
Ed, you so obviously dislike Hank Green and his videos. It is interesting 
that calling # a sharp never caught on, but there are some minor typeface 
differences. Octothorpe is possibly misleading, as octo- indicates 8, 
whereas the hash brings the number 9 to mind in its apparent 3x3 matrix 
appearance. I second your submission of a tilde for further use. If another 
symbol became necessary, I might propose &, the ampersand, which is 
actually a former "letter" that became incorrectly pronounced over time, 
originally "and, per se, and". (I hope that the sarcasm in the first 
sentence was obvious enough! :P)

comments.author: Neta Tropp

comments.text:
Before Twitter there was IRC, a great protocol for chatrooms that people 
actually still use all the time. In IRC each room is called a "channel", 
and is preceeded by an octothorpe, like you'd join the " #nerdfighters " 
channel to talk about that, or whatever.

Later on, when Twitter was growing and people wanted to talk about specific 
subjects easily (before there was threading etc), people started to use 
this notation, where you start your message with the topic of conversation 
with a # in front, and people can search for that to read everything being 
said in that "channel". Twitter noticed that people were doing this, and 
made it an Official Twitter Thing, the hashtag.

So yeah, your history is missing the use of # as an indicator of IRC 
channel names, which is believed to be how it came to be a Twitter thing.﻿
comments.author: Robert Miles

comments.text:
Also, if you're a op in a IRC channel, your name appears with an '@' in 
front of it. Possibly where twitter got that as well.
comments.author: Robert Miles

comments.text:

got the octo from it having 8 points and the thorpe from Jim Thorpe, his 
favorite athlete who at the time had unjustly been stripped of his Olympic 
medals. Also, Chris Messina deserves a mention as the inventor the Twitter 
hashtag.﻿
